A Multi-Token Coordinate Descent Method for Semi-Decentralized Vertical Federated Learning

Pedro Valdeira***Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Carnegie Mellon University; email: pvaldeira@cmu.edu. â€ â€ â€ Institute for Systems and Robotics, Instituto Superior TÃ©cnico.

IST
Abstract

Communication efficiency is a major challenge in federated learning (FL). In client-server schemes, the server constitutes a bottleneck, and while decentralized setups spread communications, they do not necessarily reduce them due to slower convergence. We propose Multi-Token Coordinate Descent (MTCD), a communication-efficient algorithm for semi-decentralized vertical federated learning, exploiting both client-server and client-client communications when each client holds a small subset of features. Our multi-token method can be seen as a parallel Markov chain (block) coordinate descent algorithm and it subsumes the client-server and decentralized setups as special cases. We obtain a convergence rate of ğ’ªâ€‹(1/T)ğ’ª1ğ‘‡\mathcal{O}(1/T) for nonconvex objectives when tokens roam over disjoint subsets of clients and for convex objectives when they roam over possibly overlapping subsets. Numerical results show that MTCD improves the state-of-the-art communication efficiency and allows for a tunable amount of parallel communications.

44footnotetext: A preliminary version of this work was presented at the 2022 NeurIPS Workshop on Federated Learning: Recent Advances and New ChallengesÂ (Valdeira etÂ al., 2022).

1 Introduction

Federated Learning (FL) is a machine learning paradigm where data is distributed across a set of clients who collaborate to learn a model without sharing local dataÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2017). Most FL literature considers data distributed by samples (horizontal FL), where each client holds all the features of a subset of the samples, yet recently there has been a growing interest on feature-distributed setups (vertical FL), where each client holds a subset of the features for all samplesÂ (He etÂ al., 2018, Chen etÂ al., 2020, Alghunaim etÂ al., 2021, Liu etÂ al., 2022b, Castiglia etÂ al., 2022). Vertical FL may be of particular interest for applications using, for example, time series data measured by personal devices to learn a model of some cross-client phenomenon of interest (e.g. meteorological), where each sample corresponds to the data collected across the devices at a given timestamp. Another example involves performing a computer vision task using multiple views of the same object, where a sample corresponds to the concatenation of views from different devices.

FL often deals with the client-server setup, where a server is connected to all clients and the clients do not communicate with each other, forming a star-shaped topology. However, such schemes have a single point of failure and suffer from a communication bottleneck on the serverÂ (Lian etÂ al., 2017). On the other hand, there is extensive literature on decentralized optimization, where there is no serverâ€”from earlier work motivated by applications such as wireless sensor networks and multiagent controlÂ (Nedic and Ozdaglar, 2009, Duchi etÂ al., 2012, Qu and Li, 2018), to recent work motivated by FLÂ (Koloskova etÂ al., 2020, Li etÂ al., 2020, Zhao etÂ al., 2022). Yet, these algorithms often converge slowly in sparse and large networksÂ (Nedic etÂ al., 2018) and, although they spread the communication load across the network, they tend to have poor communication efficiency. Semi-Decentralized FL (SDFL) uses both client-server and client-client communications, reducing the overhead at the serverÂ (Lin etÂ al., 2021) while avoiding the shortcomings of decentralized setups and being able to handle multiple clusters of clients.

When concerned with the communications between clients, the use of a token methodÂ (Bertsekas, 1997, Nedic and Bertsekas, 2001, Ram etÂ al., 2009, Johansson etÂ al., 2010, Mao etÂ al., 2020, Hendrikx, 2022), where a model-embedding token follows a random walk over a communication graph (undergoing local updates), allows for better communication efficiencyÂ (Hendrikx, 2022) than the more common consensus-based methodsÂ (Nedic and Ozdaglar, 2009, Duchi etÂ al., 2012, Qu and Li, 2018, Koloskova etÂ al., 2020). Yet, the convergence rate of token methods degrades even faster for larger and sparser networks, due to a lack of parallel communicationsÂ (Hendrikx, 2022). Based on the idea that performing multiple random walks in parallel leads to a linear speed-up in the cover timeÂ (Alon etÂ al., 2008), multi-token methodsÂ (Ye etÂ al., 2020, Chen etÂ al., 2022, Hendrikx, 2022) mitigate this problem by running multiple tokens simultaneously and combining them.

1.1 Our contribution

Motivated by the above observations, we propose an SDFL multi-token algorithm for vertical FL. Our main contributions are as follows.

  • â€¢

    We introduce Multi-Token Coordinate Descent (MTCD), which, to the best of our knowledge, is the first multi-token method leveraging the SDFL scheme to achieve a flexible degree of dependence on the server, recovering both client-server and fully decentralized FL as special cases;

  • â€¢

    We show that MTCD converges at a rate of ğ’ªâ€‹(1/T)ğ’ª1ğ‘‡\mathcal{O}(1/T) for nonconvex objectives when tokens roam over disjoint subsets of clients and for convex objectives when they roam over possibly overlapping subsets of clients;

  • â€¢

    Numerical experiments on both synthetic and real data and for a variety of communication setups show that MTCD improves the state-of-the-art communication efficiency.

1.2 Related works

Coordinate descent.

Coordinate Descent (CD) methodsÂ (Wright, 2015), where (blocks of) coordinates are updated sequentially, rather than simultaneously, are natural candidates for optimization in feature-distributed learning. The block selection is most often cyclicÂ (Beck and Tetruashvili, 2013) or independent and identically distributed at randomÂ (Nesterov, 2012, RichtÃ¡rik and TakÃ¡Ä, 2012). In contrast, Sun etÂ al. (2019) considers block selection following a Markov chain. Several extensions to CD have been proposed, such as acceleration and parallelizationÂ (Fercoq and RichtÃ¡rik, 2015) and distributed CD methodsÂ (Liu etÂ al., 2022b, Chen etÂ al., 2022).

Vertical FL.

Existing vertical FL works includeÂ He etÂ al. (2018), which generalizesÂ Smith etÂ al. (2018) to the decentralized setting. Both works use primal-dual optimization techniques, as does DCPA (Alghunaim etÂ al., 2021), a state-of-the-art decentralized method. In contrast, the following methods work in the primal domain, allowing them to learn more general models. In (Chen etÂ al., 2020), a CD-based method is used, but no local updates are performed, while Liu etÂ al. (2022b) does consider local updates. This latter work andÂ Castiglia etÂ al. (2022), which introduces the use of compressed embeddings, lowering the communication cost, are particularly close to our method. Note that the communication costs in vertical FL methods typically depend on the number of samples (or batch size, in the case of stochastic methods)Â (Alghunaim etÂ al., 2021, Liu etÂ al., 2022b, Castiglia etÂ al., 2022), further highlighting the importance of communication efficiency. An interesting line of work related to vertical FL is hybrid FLÂ (Zhang etÂ al., 2021b), which deals with datasets distributed both by samples and features. For a more detailed survey of vertical FL methods, seeÂ (Wei etÂ al., 2022, Liu etÂ al., 2022a).

Semi-Decentralized FL.

Recently, SDFL approaches have been proposed to lower communication costs and deal with data heterogeneityÂ (Lin etÂ al., 2021, Guo etÂ al., 2021), and to handle intermittent connections, latency, and stragglersÂ (Bian and Xu, 2022, Yemini etÂ al., 2022). Additionally, other SDFL works deal with (multi-layered) hierarchical networksÂ (Zhang etÂ al., 2021a, Hosseinalipour etÂ al., 2022). SDFL is also referred to as hybrid FL sometimes, but we opt for the term semi-decentralized FL to avoid confusion with the data partitioning setting mentioned above.

3 Proposed method

3.1 The fully decentralized setting

We start by introducing a simple, special case of our algorithm, which we refer to as Single-Token Coordinate Descent (STCD). This method, which is also a subroutine of our general algorithm, is closely related toÂ Sun etÂ al. (2019) and the application mentioned therein, taken fromÂ Mao etÂ al. (2020). Yet, we work in the primal domain and on a feature-distributed setting.

Setup.

In this section, we do not require the existence of a server. We solve ProblemÂ (1) in a fully decentralized manner, communicating through channels described by a communication graph ğ’¢=(ğ’±,â„°)ğ’¢ğ’±â„°\mathcal{G}=(\mathcal{V},\mathcal{E}), where ğ’±â‰”[K]â‰”ğ’±delimited-[]ğ¾\mathcal{V}\coloneqq[K] is the vertex set and â„°â„°\mathcal{E} the edge set. We denote the set of neighbors of clientÂ kğ‘˜k by ğ’©kâ‰”{i:{i,k}âˆˆâ„°}â‰”subscriptğ’©ğ‘˜conditional-setğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘˜â„°\mathcal{N}_{k}\coloneqq\{i\colon\{i,k\}\in\mathcal{E}\} and define ğ’©Â¯kâ‰”ğ’©kâˆª{k}â‰”subscriptÂ¯ğ’©ğ‘˜subscriptğ’©ğ‘˜ğ‘˜\bar{\mathcal{N}}_{k}\coloneqq\mathcal{N}_{k}\cup\{k\}. In this section only, ğœ½0subscriptğœ½0\bm{\theta}_{0} is associated with some clientÂ kğ‘˜k, which is responsible for updating both the local model it holds, ğœ½ksubscriptğœ½ğ‘˜\bm{\theta}_{k}, and the fusion model ğœ½0subscriptğœ½0\bm{\theta}_{0}.444We do this for alignment with the analysis inÂ Sun etÂ al. (2019), where all blocks are selected following a Markov Chain. However, in practice, we may want to update ğœ½0subscriptğœ½0\bm{\theta}_{0} at each client instead, in which case the analysis would need to be adjusted.

    This allows us to perform multiple local CD steps. Further, after these Qğ‘„Q steps, the updated token can be sent to clientÂ ks+1superscriptğ‘˜ğ‘ 1k^{s+1}. Thus, by induction, we keep the token up-to-date throughout our algorithm.

  • â€¢

    Communicating the token: the token is communicated to a neighbor of kssuperscriptğ‘˜ğ‘ k^{s}. This results in a sequence of clients (and blocks) that follows a Markov Chain.

In essence, STCD is a technique allowing for Markov Chain Coordinate DescentÂ (Sun etÂ al., 2019) to be performed in feature-distributed setups. In terms of the progress made in the parameter space, AlgorithmÂ 1 differs from Sun etÂ al. (2019) only in that we consider local updates with Q>1ğ‘„1Q>1.

Convergence guarantees.

Further, Ï„ğœ\tau denotes the Ï€min2subscriptğœ‹2\frac{\pi_{\min}}{2}-mixing time of the the Markov chain. (We present all the aforementioned Markov chain-related terms in AppendixÂ A.) While Sun etÂ al. (2019) only consider Q=1ğ‘„1Q=1 explicitly, their analysis can also cover the Q>1ğ‘„1Q>1 case. To see this, consider a virtual dynamic graph ğ’¢r=(ğ’±,â„°r)superscriptğ’¢ğ‘Ÿğ’±superscriptâ„°ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{G}^{r}=(\mathcal{V},\mathcal{E}^{r}) where ğ’±ğ’±\mathcal{V} is the original vertex set and, recalling that â„°â„°\mathcal{E} is the original edge set,

To see this, let ğ‘·ğ‘·\bm{P} denote the transition matrix of a random walk on the original graph ğ’¢ğ’¢\mathcal{G} and let ğ‘·â€‹(r)ğ‘·ğ‘Ÿ\bm{P}(r) denote the transition matrix of a random walk on ğ’¢rsuperscriptğ’¢ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{G}^{r}. Assuming, for simplicity, that Râ‰¥Qğ‘…ğ‘„R\geq Q, we have that ğ‘·â€‹(r)â€‹ğ‘·â€‹(r+1)â€‹â€¦â€‹ğ‘·â€‹(r+R)=ğ‘·âŒŠR/QâŒ‹ğ‘·ğ‘Ÿğ‘·ğ‘Ÿ1â€¦ğ‘·ğ‘Ÿğ‘…superscriptğ‘·ğ‘…ğ‘„\bm{P}(r)\bm{P}(r+1)\dots\bm{P}(r+R)=\bm{P}^{\lfloor R/Q\rfloor}. We thus recover the results inÂ Sun etÂ al. (2019) up to a factor of Qğ‘„Q in the mixing time. (That is, inÂ (3), we replace Ï„ğœ\tau by Qâ€‹Ï„ğ‘„ğœQ\tau.)

Limitations.

The decentralized token algorithm in this section has an appealing simplicity. However, while it outperforms state-of-the-art feature-distributed learning algorithms in a variety of setups, as we will see in SectionÂ 4, its performance deteriorates faster with network connectivity than these decentralized consensus-based algorithms and its convergence per iteration can be rather slow. These problems will be mitigated by the more general multi-token method presented next.

3.2 Semi-decentralized setting

In SectionÂ 3.1, we introduced a special case of MTCD where a single token roams over a fully decentralized set of clients. We now present our method in the semi-decentralized setting, which subsumes the setting in SectionÂ 3.1 as a special case. Multi-token CD alternates between a roaming step and a syncing step.

  • â€¢

    Roaming. We start with multiple, matching tokens at a subset of the clients. As each token performs a different random walk realization, they undergo different sequences of CD updates, becoming distinct.

  • â€¢

    Syncing. To leverage these parallel computations while keeping our model estimates coupled, we periodically sync the roaming tokens at the server, combining the progress of multiple CD sequences.

By alternating between these two steps, we get a communication-efficient algorithm with a flexible degree of parallelization, depending on the number of tokens and the frequency at which we sync them. This allows us to smoothly control the trade off between the communication efficiency of settings with less parallel computations and the faster iteration convergence of settings with more parallel computations.

We further generalize STCD by allowing the use of stochastic gradient estimates. Let ğ‘©âˆˆâ„BÃ—dğ‘©superscriptâ„ğµğ‘‘\bm{B}\in\mathbb{R}^{B\times d} denote a mini-batch of size BğµB defined by a random set of indices â„¬âŠ†[N]â„¬delimited-[]ğ‘\mathcal{B}\subseteq[N], we make the following standard assumptions that our gradient estimate is unbiased and has a bounded variance. For clarity, we make the dependency on ğ‘¿ğ‘¿\bm{X} explicit by writing âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğœ½;ğ‘¿)=âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğœ½)âˆ‡ğ‘“ğœ½ğ‘¿âˆ‡ğ‘“ğœ½\nabla f(\bm{\theta};\bm{X})=\nabla f(\bm{\theta}).

Assumption 2 (Unbiased gradients).

For any mini-batch ğğ\bm{B}, the stochastic gradient is unbiased:

ğ”¼â„¬â€‹[âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğœ½;ğ‘©)]=âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğœ½;ğ‘¿),âˆ€ğœ½âˆˆâ„d.formulae-sequencesubscriptğ”¼â„¬delimited-[]âˆ‡ğ‘“ğœ½ğ‘©âˆ‡ğ‘“ğœ½ğ‘¿for-allğœ½superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{B}}[\nabla f(\bm{\theta};\bm{B})]=\nabla f(\bm{\theta};\bm{X}),\quad\forall\;\bm{\theta}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}. (A2)
Assumption 3 (Bounded variance).

For any mini-batch ğğ\bm{B}, there exists a constant Ïƒâ‰¥0ğœ0\sigma\geq 0 such that:

Recovering client-server and decentralized setups.

On the one hand, if no client-server communications are available (Sâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘†S\to\infty), our algorithm is reduced to a fully decentralized one, recovering STCD. On the other hand, if the edge set â„°â„°\mathcal{E} is empty, we recover the client-server setting. In this case, if we assign a token to each client (Î“=KÎ“ğ¾\Gamma=K and each PÎ³subscriptğ‘ƒğ›¾P_{\gamma} has support over a single different client), we get full participation, as in Liu etÂ al. (2022b). In contrast, if Î“<KÎ“ğ¾\Gamma<K, we recover a partial participation client-server scheme. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first partial participation vertical FL algorithm with multiple local updates.

In general, as we increase the amount of parallel computations (by increasing Î“Î“\Gamma) and client-server communications (by lowering Sğ‘†S), the communication efficiency and the number of iterations needed to converge both decrease. Given this trade-off, we see that our choice of Sğ‘†S and Î“Î“\Gamma depends on the application.

Having introduced the general MTCD algorithm, we now go over two particular instances of it, both for semi-decentralized setups, and present convergence guarantees for each.

Setting with a token per cluster.

We now present some convergence guarantees for MTCD in the case where we have Cğ¶C disjoint clusters of clients ğ’1,â€¦,ğ’Csubscriptğ’1â€¦subscriptğ’ğ¶\mathcal{C}_{1},\dots,\mathcal{C}_{C} and one token roams each cluster, hence Î“=CÎ“ğ¶\Gamma=C. Without loss of generality, we assume Î³ğ›¾\gamma roams ğ’Î³subscriptğ’ğ›¾\mathcal{C}_{\gamma}, allowing us to use Î³ğ›¾\gamma and cğ‘c interchangeably. Thus, PÎ³subscriptğ‘ƒğ›¾P_{\gamma} has support over ğ’Î³subscriptğ’ğ›¾\mathcal{C}_{\gamma}, and only over ğ’Î³subscriptğ’ğ›¾\mathcal{C}_{\gamma}. We also define a cluster containing only the server, ğ’0â‰”{0}â‰”subscriptğ’00\mathcal{C}_{0}\coloneqq\{0\}.

These clusters may correspond to the natural topology of the communication graph, due to physical limitations or to privacy constraints preventing communications between clients in different clusters (e.g., households or companies). Yet, we may also generate artificial partitioning of the original graph, prior to learning our model, in order to allow for the use of multiple tokens while avoiding overlapping trajectories, rather than having a single token roaming over a too large (and thus poorly connected) graph.

Since in this setting the blocks of coordinates being updated in each model estimate are disjoint, we let ğ’˜kâˆˆâ„Î“subscriptğ’˜ğ‘˜superscriptâ„Î“\bm{w}_{k}\in\mathbb{R}^{\Gamma} be the one-hot encoding for the token that visits clientÂ kğ‘˜k, thus combining the model estimates by simply taking the updated version of each block.

Setting with overlapping token trajectories.

We now present some convergence guarantees for MTCD in the setting where we allow for overlapping token trajectories. We propose choosing the convex combination weights to be ğ’˜k=(1Î“,â€¦,1Î“)âˆˆâ„Î“subscriptğ’˜ğ‘˜1Î“â€¦1Î“superscriptâ„Î“\bm{w}_{k}=(\frac{1}{\Gamma},\dots,\frac{1}{\Gamma})\in\mathbb{R}^{\Gamma} for all kğ‘˜k, thus combining the model estimates by averaging them. In this setting, to handle the periodic combination by averaging of the model estimates, we develop convergence guarantees for convex objectives. The standard definition of convexity is given below.

Assumption 4 (Convexity).

A function f:â„dâ†¦â„:ğ‘“maps-tosuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘â„f\colon\mathbb{R}^{d}\mapsto\mathbb{R} is convex if for all aâˆˆ[0,1]ğ‘01a\in[0,1]:

4 Experiments

We test our method empirically, comparing it to DCPAÂ (Alghunaim etÂ al., 2021), a state-of-the-art fully decentralized method, and a standard vertical FL (S-VFL) method which, since we do not consider compression in our experiments, coincides with both C-VFLÂ (Castiglia etÂ al., 2022) and FedBCDÂ (Liu etÂ al., 2022b). Note that, while some trajectories have a small variance, making the confidence interval hard to see, all experiments are run for 5 seeds.

4.1 Convex problems

In this section, we use CVXPYÂ (Diamond and Boyd, 2016) to obtain fâ‹†superscriptğ‘“â‹†f^{\star}, to use the (relative) suboptimality gap fâ€‹(ğœ½t)âˆ’fâ‹†fâ‹†ğ‘“superscriptğœ½ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘“â‹†superscriptğ‘“â‹†\frac{f(\bm{\theta}^{t})-f^{\star}}{f^{\star}} as a metric. For simplicity, we assume CCâ€‹2â€‹Ssubscriptğ¶ğ¶2ğ‘†C_{C2S} is the same for communications from the client to the server and vice-versa, although this is often not the case. For MTCD, we assume a uniform distribution over the clients when resuming roaming. In SectionÂ 4.1, we allow for the tokens to overlap.

We perform ridge regression on a dataset generated following the same process asÂ (Alghunaim etÂ al., 2021), with N=1000ğ‘1000N=1000 samples and d=2000ğ‘‘2000d=2000 features split evenly across clients. Fully decentralized setting.

In FigureÂ 3, we see that, while MTCD with Sâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘†S\to\infty and Î“=1Î“1\Gamma=1 (that is, STCD) does not improve upon DCPA in terms of progress per iteration, it is significantly more communication efficient. Yet, STCD is particularly vulnerable to poorly connected networks, as seen when going from an ErdÅ‘sâ€“RÃ©nyi graph to a path graph. Note that, for sparse logistic regression, while the proximal term used to handle the regularizer is not covered by our analysis, it does well empirically. FigureÂ 4 shows additional ridge regression experiments in the Nâ‰«dmuch-greater-thanğ‘ğ‘‘N\gg d regime across six different graph topologies.

SDFL setting.

We now tackle the same ridge regression problem, now focusing on path graphs, where poor connectivity is a greater challenge. In FigureÂ 5, we see in the top row that our method improves upon the communication efficiency of the other methods. When plotting the number of communications needed to attain a suboptimality gap of 10âˆ’4superscript10410^{-4} for each CCâ€‹2â€‹C/CCâ€‹2â€‹Ssubscriptğ¶ğ¶2ğ¶subscriptğ¶ğ¶2ğ‘†C_{C2C}/C_{C2S}, we see that, for different values of CCâ€‹2â€‹C/CCâ€‹2â€‹Ssubscriptğ¶ğ¶2ğ¶subscriptğ¶ğ¶2ğ‘†C_{C2C}/C_{C2S}, the communication efficiency of SDFL methods varies. In the bottom row, we see that, as we increase the syncing frequency, the convergence per iterations speeds up and the communication efficiency decreases, as expected. This illustrates the flexibility of our method, which allows us to choose a regime at which to operate.

4.2 Neural network training

We train an MVCNNÂ (Su etÂ al., 2015) model on ModelNet10Â (Wu etÂ al., 2015), a dataset of 3D CAD models. We consider 121212 clients split into two clusters of six clients, each capturing a different (2D) view of each object, and run MTCD for both complete and path graphs with S=6ğ‘†6S=6. We use a fixed Î·=0.001ğœ‚0.001\eta=0.001 for S-VFL. When running MTCD on 2 complete graph clusters with 6 clients each, we also start with Î·=0.001ğœ‚0.001\eta=0.001 but halve it every 20 epochs. On the path graph clusters, we start with Î·=0.0005ğœ‚0.0005\eta=0.0005 and halve it every 20 epochs. For both both types of graph, we use S=6ğ‘†6S=6. We use Q=10ğ‘„10Q=10 and a batch size of 64 for both MTCD and S-VFL.

We also train a ResNet18Â (He etÂ al., 2016) on CIFAR-10Â (Krizhevsky etÂ al., 2009), for K=4ğ¾4K=4 and two clusters (2 clients each). For MTCD, we use S=2ğ‘†2S=2. We use a fixed Î·=0.0001ğœ‚0.0001\eta=0.0001, Q=10ğ‘„10Q=10 and a batch size of 100 for both S-VFL and MTCD. For MTCD, we use S=2ğ‘†2S=2.

In FigureÂ 6, we present the results of the ModelNet10 and the CIFAR-10 experiments, both in the token-per-cluster setting. In both, we observe a similar performace in terms of convergence per iteration, but that MTCD outperforms the baseline in communication efficiency.

5 Conclusions

We formalize the multi-token SDFL scheme and propose MTCD, a communication-efficient SDFL algorithm for vertical FL. We provide convergence guarantees for our method and show empirically the improved communication efficiency of our algorithm as well as the power of endowing decentralized methods with periodical client-server communications. A natural extension to this work is to consider compression and privacy mechanisms, such as differential privacy.

Remark (GrÃ¶nwall-Bellman lemma).

Let a,bâ‰¥0ğ‘ğ‘0a,b\geq 0 be constants, if sequence (un)n=0Nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘›ğ‘›0ğ‘(u_{n})_{n=0}^{N} satisfies

(6)
Proof.

where in (a)ğ‘(a) we use the finite sum of a geometric series, which is equal to the expression that follows for the case b>0ğ‘0b>0 and, to handle b=0ğ‘0b=0, we can use Bernoulliâ€™s inequality. âˆ

Consider the set of vectors {ğ’‚1,â€¦,ğ’‚n}subscriptğ’‚1â€¦subscriptğ’‚ğ‘›\{\bm{a}_{1},\dots,\bm{a}_{n}\}, using the Cauchyâ€“Schwarz inequality we have that:

(7)
